expanded_description: Logarithms are the inverses of exponential functions. Just as subtraction undoes addition and division undoes multiplication, logarithms undo exponentiation. The logarithm base $b$ of a number $x$ answers the question: "To what power must we raise $b$ to get $x$?" Understanding logarithms as inverses of exponentials is the foundation for working with logarithmic functions, solving exponential equations, and modeling many real-world phenomena where quantities grow or decay exponentially.

core_concept.principle:
For $b > 0$, $b \neq 1$, the logarithmic function $y = \log_b x$ is the inverse of the exponential function $y = b^x$. This means:
• $\log_b x = y$ if and only if $b^y = x$
• $\log_b(b^x) = x$ for all $x$
• $b^{\log_b x} = x$ for all $x > 0$
core_concept.explanation: Think of a logarithm as a question: "What exponent gives me this number?" For example, $\log_2 8 = 3$ because $2^3 = 8$. The base $b$ of the logarithm is the same as the base of the exponential. Just as the square root function answers "what number squared gives me this?", the logarithm answers "what power of the base gives me this?" This inverse relationship is the key to understanding all logarithmic properties.

image.alt: Diagram showing the inverse relationship between y = b^x and y = log_b x, with symmetry about y=x.
image.caption: Logarithms and Exponentials: Inverse functions.

sections.introduction: The logarithm is defined as the inverse of an exponential function. Understanding this definition is the first step in working with logarithms.

key_concept.definition: If $b > 0$, $b \neq 1$, and $x > 0$, then $\log_b x = y$ means $b^y = x$. In words: "$\log_b x$ is the exponent to which $b$ must be raised to get $x$."
key_concept.context: The base $b$ must be positive and not equal to 1. The argument $x$ must be positive because any positive base raised to any real exponent is positive.

process_flow.description: In $\log_b x$, $b$ is the base and $x$ is the argument.
process_flow.mechanism: The base is written as a subscript; the argument is the number after the base.

process_flow.description: $\log_b x = y$ is equivalent to $b^y = x$.

process_flow.process: Convert from Exponential to Logarithmic Form
process_flow.description: $b^y = x$ is equivalent to $\log_b x = y$.

worked_examples.title: Converting Between Forms
worked_examples.problem: Convert each exponential equation to logarithmic form and each logarithmic equation to exponential form: a) $3^4 = 81$ b) $\log_2 32 = 5$ c) $10^{-2} = 0.01$ d) $\log_5 \frac{1}{25} = -2$

image.alt: Conversion between exponential and logarithmic forms.
image.caption: Converting Forms: $\log_b x = y \iff b^y = x$.

worked_examples.concept_applied: The logarithm is the exponent. Converting between forms is essential for understanding logarithms.

image.alt: Definition: log_b x = y means b^y = x.
image.caption: Definition of Logarithms: The exponent interpretation.

sections.introduction: Evaluating a logarithm means finding its value. This is done by converting to exponential form and determining the exponent.

key_concept.definition: To evaluate $\log_b x$, ask: "What power of $b$ equals $x$?" If $x$ can be written as $b^y$, then $\log_b x = y$.
key_concept.context: Many logarithms can be evaluated mentally by recognizing powers of the base. For example, $\log_3 81 = 4$ because $3^4 = 81$. For values that are not obvious powers, calculators are used.

process_flow.description: Since the bases are the same, the exponents must be equal.

worked_examples.title: Evaluating Logarithms

image.alt: Examples of evaluating logarithms.
image.caption: Evaluating Logarithms: Find the exponent that gives the argument.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Rewrite the argument as a power of the base; the exponent is the logarithm.

image.alt: Process: log_b x = y → b^y = x → find y.
image.caption: Evaluating Logarithms: Convert to exponential form.

sections.introduction: Two special logarithms have their own notation: common logarithm (base 10) and natural logarithm (base $e$). They appear frequently in applications.

key_concept.definition:
• Common logarithm: $\log x$ means $\log_{10} x$
• Natural logarithm: $\ln x$ means $\log_e x$, where $e \approx 2.71828$
key_concept.context: Common logarithms are often used in science and engineering because of our base-10 number system. Natural logarithms arise naturally in calculus and in models of continuous growth. Most calculators have dedicated $\log$ and $\ln$ buttons.

characteristics: Used in pH, Richter scale, decibels

image.alt: Graph of y = log x (base 10).
image.caption: Common Logarithm: Base 10.

image.alt: Graph of y = ln x (base e).
image.caption: Natural Logarithm: Base $e$.

worked_examples.title: Common and Natural Logarithms
worked_examples.problem: Evaluate: a) $\log 1000$ b) $\log 0.0001$ c) $\ln e^5$ d) $\ln 1$ e) $\ln e$

image.alt: Examples of common and natural logarithms.
image.caption: Common and Natural Logarithms: Special notations.

worked_examples.concept_applied: $\log$ means base 10, $\ln$ means base $e$. Use the same definition: the exponent that gives the argument.

image.alt: Common log (log) and natural log (ln) notations.
image.caption: Special Logarithms: $\log$ (base 10) and $\ln$ (base $e$).

sections.introduction: Because logarithms and exponentials are inverses, they undo each other. These inverse properties are fundamental for simplifying expressions and solving equations.

key_concept.context: These properties say that applying a logarithm to an exponential (with the same base) returns the exponent, and applying an exponential to a logarithm returns the argument. They are direct consequences of the definition of inverses.

process_flow.mechanism: The base of the log and the base of the exponential must match.
The log and exponential cancel, leaving the exponent or argument.

worked_examples.title: Using Inverse Properties

image.alt: Examples of inverse properties: log_b(b^x) = x and b^{log_b x} = x.
image.caption: Inverse Properties: Exponentials and logarithms undo each other.

worked_examples.concept_applied: When the base of the log and the base of the exponential match, they cancel.

image.alt: Inverse properties: log_b(b^x) = x and b^{log_b x} = x.
image.caption: Inverse Properties: The foundation of logarithmic manipulation.

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Working with logarithms as inverses of exponentials has several common pitfalls. Here's what to watch for.

classifications.value: Mixing up which number is the base and which is the argument in $\log_b x$
characteristics: Not understanding that the base is the subscript
classifications.behavior: Completely wrong interpretation; leads to incorrect evaluations.

image.alt: Correct: log_2 8 = 3 because 2^3=8. Incorrect: thinking 2^8=256.
image.caption: $\log_b x$ asks for the exponent on $b$ that gives $x$.

classifications.note: Solution: Remember: $\log_b x = y$ means $b^y = x$. The base is $b$, the logarithm is the exponent.

classifications.value: Trying to take the logarithm of a non-positive number
characteristics: Writing $\log(-5)$ as if it were defined
Not recognizing that arguments must be positive

image.alt: log x is only defined for x > 0.
image.caption: Domain of Logarithms: $x > 0$.

examples.explanation:
Mistake: Trying to evaluate.
Correct: Undefined (not a real number).

classifications.note: Solution: The argument of a logarithm must be positive. If you encounter $\log(0)$ or $\log(\text{negative})$, the expression is undefined.

classifications.value: Using $\log_b(b^x) = x$ when the bases don't match
characteristics: Not checking that the base of the log equals the base of the exponential

image.alt: Correct: log_2(2^x) = x. Incorrect: log_2(3^x) = x.
image.caption: Inverse properties require matching bases.

examples.explanation:
Mistake: $= x$.
Correct: Cannot simplify directly; bases don't match.

classifications.note: Solution: The inverse properties only work when the base of the logarithm and the base of the exponential are the same.

classifications.value: Treating $\log$ and $\ln$ as interchangeable without considering the base
classifications.behavior: Numerical errors; misunderstanding of different bases.

image.caption: $\log$ (base 10) and $\ln$ (base $e$) are different.

classifications.note: Solution: Remember that $\log$ means base 10 (common log) and $\ln$ means base $e$ (natural log). They are not the same.

image.alt: Infographic showing four common logarithm mistakes with corrections.
image.caption: Common Errors: Watch for these when working with logarithms.

sections.introduction: Logarithms appear throughout science and engineering as inverses of exponential functions.

categories.description: pH is defined as $\text{pH} = -\log_{10}[H^+]$, where $[H^+]$ is the hydrogen ion concentration. Logarithms convert wide-ranging concentrations into a manageable 0-14 scale.

image.alt: pH scale with common substances.
image.caption: pH Scale: A logarithmic measure of acidity.

categories.description: The Richter scale for earthquake magnitude is logarithmic: $M = \log_{10}(I/I_0)$. Each unit increase represents a tenfold increase in intensity.

image.alt: Richter scale with earthquake effects.
image.caption: Richter Scale: Logarithmic measure of earthquake intensity.

examples.explanation: A magnitude 6 earthquake is $10^{6-5} = 10$ times more intense than a magnitude 5 earthquake.

categories.description: Sound intensity is measured in decibels: $\text{dB} = 10 \log_{10}(I/I_0)$. The logarithmic scale matches human perception of loudness.

image.alt: Decibel scale with common sounds.
image.caption: Decibel Scale: Logarithmic measure of sound intensity.

examples.explanation: A 20 dB sound is $10^{(20-10)/10} = 10^1 = 10$ times more intense than a 10 dB sound.

sections.introduction: Let's combine all the concepts—converting between forms, evaluating logarithms, using inverse properties, and working with common and natural logs—in comprehensive problems.

worked_examples.title: Comprehensive Logarithm Introduction Problem
worked_examples.problem:
a) Write $5^3 = 125$ in logarithmic form.
b) Write $\log_4 64 = 3$ in exponential form.
c) Evaluate $\log_7 49$.
d) Evaluate $\log_2 \frac{1}{32}$.
e) Simplify $\log_5(5^{2x-1})$.
f) Simplify $e^{\ln 7}$.
g) Evaluate $\ln e^4$.
h) Evaluate $\log 0.001$.

image.alt: Eight logarithm problems with solutions.
image.caption: Comprehensive Practice: Introduction to logarithms.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Each part uses different aspects of logarithms: conversion, evaluation, inverse properties, and special notations.

summary: Logarithms are the inverses of exponential functions: $\log_b x = y$ means $b^y = x$. The base $b$ must be positive and not equal to 1, and the argument $x$ must be positive. Converting between exponential and logarithmic forms is essential: $b^y = x \iff \log_b x = y$. To evaluate a logarithm, rewrite the argument as a power of the base. Special notations include common logarithm ($\log x = \log_{10} x$) and natural logarithm ($\ln x = \log_e x$). The inverse properties state that $\log_b(b^x) = x$ and $b^{\log_b x} = x$, which hold when the bases match. Common mistakes include confusing the base and argument, forgetting domain restrictions (arguments must be positive), misapplying inverse properties with mismatched bases, and confusing $\log$ and $\ln$. Logarithms are used in real-world applications such as pH (acidity), Richter scale (earthquakes), and decibels (sound intensity).

review_questions_image.alt: Visual summary: Definition of logarithms, conversion between forms, evaluating logs, common/natural logs, inverse properties, and common mistakes.
review_questions_image.caption: Unit 6.7 Review: Introduction to logarithms as inverses of exponentials.
